intro: Heteranthocidium silvanoi, commonly known as the Sierra Valley bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in moist meadows and along stream banks, preferring cool, temperate climates. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a hairy texture, while its stems are erect and branching. Heteranthocidium silvanoi plays a role in supporting local pollinators and contributes to the biodiversity of its native habitat.
